title: Sources
text:
The project uses data from IPUMS Microdata of people with income, English proficiency, and other demographics. I used tidyverse to omit some of these variables and only get required columns and rows. We used a random sample-sized 500,000 rows.

Dataset

Title: American Community Surveys (ACS)
Time Period: 2021-2023
Source: U.S. Census
Link: View Dataset

title: Insights
text:
This income distribution plot demonstrates clear education and gender premiums, with graduate degree holders earning substantially more than those with less education and males consistently out-earning females across all groups. Limited English Proficiency appears to have a modest negative impact on income, particularly at higher education levels, while significant income inequality is evident through extensive high-income outliers reaching $750,000+ across all subgroups.









This education distribution plot reveals a stark educational divide between LEP groups, with Limited English Proficiency individuals heavily concentrated in lower education levels (nearly 50% have less than high school education) while English proficient individuals are more evenly distributed across education levels and comprise the majority of those with graduate degrees (around 40%).

title: About
text:
Hello, I’m Faisal Jan from Turbat, Pakistan. I love to work on Data Science and AI projects that are used to solve real world problems. You can find some of my projects on GitHub or let’s connect to discuss your project at faisaljanfazal@yahoo.com.
This project examines the effect of Limited English Proficiency (LEP) on a person’s income when controlling other variables, such as education level and gender.
You can view the project repository on GitHub.
This project was created as a part of Kane’s Data Science Bootcamp.

title: Limited English Profiency on Income Levels
text: Language proficiency is one of the key requirements in almost every job posting, and being proficient in a language can open new doors for an individual. Using a sample of data drawn from the American Community Surveys (U.S. Census) of 2021-2023, I seek to examine the effect of Limited English proficiency on a person’s income in the USA. I used R to look at the insights into how Limited English Proficiency (LEP) effects a person’s wage when controling education level and gender. I modeled a person’s income, as a linear function of her English profiency, education level, and gender. Across all education levels, males earn 20–50% more than females, with the largest gender and language-based income gaps appearing at the graduate level where English Proficient males earn over $70,000, nearly 50% more than their female counterparts.

title: Model
text:
The outcome variable in our model is the natural logarithm of income (log_income), and it is modeled as a linear function of English proficiency (lep), education level (educ_level), and gender (gender). The fitted model is:
\[
\begin{aligned}
\log(\text{income})_i =\;& 9.62 \\
&- 0.0385 \cdot \text{LEP}_i \\
&+ 0.227 \cdot \text{HighSchool}_i \\
&+ 0.274 \cdot \text{SomeCollege}_i \\
&+ 0.402 \cdot \text{Bachelors}_i \\
&+ 1.14 \cdot \text{Graduate}_i \\
&+ 0.419 \cdot \text{Male}_i \\
&+ \varepsilon_i
\end{aligned}
\]
Where:

LEP = 1 if individual has limited English proficiency, 0 otherwise

HighSchool, SomeCollege, Bachelors, Graduate are dummy variables for education level

Male = 1 if individual is male, 0 if female

The reference category is female English-proficient individuals with less than high school education

To recover predicted income in dollars, we exponentiate the log outcome:
\[
\text{income} = \exp(\log(\text{income}))
\]

text:
The outcome variable in our model is the natural logarithm of income (log_income), and it is modeled as a linear function of English proficiency (lep), education level (educ_level), and gender (gender). The fitted model is:
\[
\begin{aligned}
\log(\text{income})_i =\;& 9.62 \\
&- 0.0385 \cdot \text{LEP}_i \\
&+ 0.227 \cdot \text{HighSchool}_i \\
&+ 0.274 \cdot \text{SomeCollege}_i \\
&+ 0.402 \cdot \text{Bachelors}_i \\
&+ 1.14 \cdot \text{Graduate}_i \\
&+ 0.419 \cdot \text{Male}_i \\
&+ \varepsilon_i

Where:

LEP = 1 if individual has limited English proficiency, 0 otherwise

HighSchool, SomeCollege, Bachelors, Graduate are dummy variables for education level

Male = 1 if individual is male, 0 if female

The reference category is female English-proficient individuals with less than high school education

To recover predicted income in dollars, we exponentiate the log outcome:
\[
\text{income} = \exp(\log(\text{income}))
\]
